user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_suspend_connection:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_suspend_connection (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME))
    MHD_PANIC (_ ("Cannot suspend connections without " \
                  "enabling MHD_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME!\n"));
#ifdef UPGRADE_SUPPORT
  if (NULL != connection->urh)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Error: connection scheduled for \"upgrade\" cannot " \
                 "be suspended.\n"));
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
    return;
  }
#endif /* UPGRADE_SUPPORT */
  internal_suspend_connection_ (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The fragment is guarded by a preprocessor #ifdef (MHD_USE_THREADS); when that macro is defined the assertion is part of the translation unit and reachable at run-time (it does not create any unreachable control-flow); when the macro is not defined the code is omitted from the translation unit (omission by preprocessor is not “unreachable code” under Rule 2.1). A concrete Rule 2.1 violation would require code that can never be executed due to program control-flow (for example code after an unconditional return or an infinite loop in the same translation unit), which is not present here.
